metadata.notes: A classic homiletic style that balances emotional resonance with theological assertion.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids harsh 'musts' and legalism. Instead of condemning the listener for lack of faith, he identifies with the struggle ('cuts against our grain'). However, there is a subtle CP presence in the 'imperious word of Jesus' which demands submission.
quotes: Our natural grain isâ€”if we have to do it to go frowning and pouting.
The imperious word of Jesus is 'Carry me to the tomb.'

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong here, focusing on God's empathy and suffering. It promotes comfort without creating a helpless dependency, though it leans into the 'Rescuer' role of the divine.
quotes: When we come to the grave of Lazarus and see Jesus weep, we are brought inevitably to the conclusion that God can suffer.

adult.analysis: The preacher uses Adult logic to analyze language ('Words do not create things, but things create words') and acknowledges the reality of death ('Kaput! Finis!'). However, the Adult is eventually bypassed for a mystical 'believing is seeing' conclusion.
quotes: If you will look at your own Christian life carefully enough, you will discover that it is made up of that combination of attraction and repulsion.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher does not use fear-based tactics to force compliance. He acknowledges the 'terrifying' nature of Jesus but frames it as an authentic reaction rather than a tool for control.
quotes: There is also some quality... something almost terrifyingly earnest about him that makes us draw back.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a poetic, almost playful use of language ('Kaput!', 'roundhouse'), but the overall tone is more somber and reflective than joyful.
quotes: Maybe our Lord had forgotten the people he was talking to. He started talking the language of his native land.

transaction_analysis.primary_transaction_style: Adult -> Adult (Invitation to reflection) shifting to Parent -> Child (Comfort/Assurance)
transaction_analysis.analysis: The sermon begins with an Adult invitation to self-observation ('look squarely at ourselves'). It then shifts to a Nurturing Parent role, providing theological comfort regarding the nature of God's tears.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The social level is 'Let us study the text,' while the psychological level is 'I will show you a God who hurts so you feel safe.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The risk is a 'Bait and Switch' where the preacher uses the 'Adult' reality of death to set up a 'Parental' miracle that bypasses human logic.

detected_games.name: Redemption / Bait & Switch

formula_g_analysis.con: Acknowledge the harsh reality of death and decomposition (Adult).
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's fear of finality and 'stink' of failure.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from the 'hopelessness' of the grave to the 'imperious' power of the word.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A sense of relief and submission to the divine authority.

evidence_quotes: Not only is Lazarus dead, but the body is decomposed. Finality! Finality!
The power of Christ is not finally frustrated by his tears. He summons Lazarus from the grave.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The sermon is remarkably low on 'NIGYSOB' or 'Ain't it Awful.' It maintains a high level of respect for the listener's internal experience.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. The preacher presents Jesus (and by extension, the sermon) as the solution to the 'finality' of death.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low. Very little blame is assigned to the listener.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. The preacher briefly mentions 'our refusal of God's company' as a cause for God's tears, but doesn't dwell on it.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is positioned as the 'Victim' of mortality and 'natural grain,' needing the 'Rescuer' (Grace/Jesus).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The escape is offered through 'choice' and 'venturing forth,' moving the listener back toward Adult autonomy.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is psychologically healthy and largely avoids manipulative games. It respects the listener's Adult ego by acknowledging the difficulty of faith and the reality of death. While it uses the Nurturing Parent position to offer comfort, it does so without shaming the 'Child' or demanding blind submission. The primary dynamic is an invitation to trust rather than a demand for obedience.
strengths: High level of empathy and identification with the listener.
Strong Adult processing of the reality of grief.
areas_for_improvement: The 'imperious word' section leans slightly into Critical Parent territory.
The transition from 'decomposition' to 'miracle' could involve more Adult reflection on how one 'ventures forth' in the modern world.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue to use the 'we' pronoun to maintain the Adult-Adult partnership. Ensure that the 'believing is seeing' concept is presented as a personal choice for the listener rather than a parental command.
